cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
where is the tablet of the ten commandments
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The Ten Commandments, according to the Bible, were given to Moses on Mount Sinai and were inscribed on two tablets of stone. The location of these tablets is a subject of religious tradition and belief. Historically, they were housed in the Ark of the Covenant, a sacred container described in the Hebrew Bible. The Ark was said to have been kept in the Holy of Holies within the Tabernacle and later in the Temple in Jerusalem. However, the fate of the Ark and the tablets is uncertain, as they are believed to have been lost or hidden during the Babylonian conquest of Jerusalem in 586 BCE. Various theories and legends exist about their whereabouts, but there is no definitive evidence of their current location.

Answer: The tablets of the Ten Commandments are traditionally believed to have been housed in the Ark of the Covenant, but their current location is unknown.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
where is the tablet of the ten commandments
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Ten Commandments appear on the Menorah in their traditional form of two rectangular tablets with rounded tops. Written on the tablets are the Ten Commandments as given at Mount Sinai encapsulating the basic tenets of Jewish faith and values. Each commandment is represented on the tablets by the first two words of the full commandment. Flames rise in the background of the tablets, symbolizing the burning bush or Mount Sinai aflame at the Giving of the Torah.\n', 'The map has decorative enframes-cartouches on its sides, with two big cartouches at the top quadrants and two small ones at the bottom quadrants. The big cartouche at the top left shows the biblical Israeli leaders Moses and Aaron placing their hands on Israel\'s Tablets of the Law with the Ten Commandments inscribed in Hebrew. Above them at the top of the cartouche frame within another frame, appears a caption of the Hebrew word "יְהֹוָה" - "YHWH", the tetragrammaton as the most sacred name of God. The big cartouche at the top right quadrant shows the biblical story of Adam and Eve in Paradise, which is based on Albrecht Dürer\'s engraving from 1504 under the title "Adam and Eve" - with small differences between the two. Above them at the top of the cartouche frame within another frame, appears a caption of the Hebrew word "אֱלֹהִים" - "Elohim" as the second name of God. The small cartouche at the bottom left quadrant shows a heraldic eagle and an inscription to sir Robert Cotton who encouraged Speed to start drawing maps.\n', 'The Master of the Altarpiece of the Ten Commandments () was a German painter active in the region of Göttingen at the beginning of the fifteenth century. His name is derived from a portable altarpiece, depicting the Ten Commandments, which is believed to have at one time stood in the chapel of the Sacred Heart in Göttingen, constructed in 1319. Only the central part of the painting survives, today in the history museum in Hannover; it depicts six scenes in two registers, showing the second, third, fourth, seventh, eight, and ninth Commandments. The wings, illustrating the other four, are now lost. At the top of the composition is a half-length figure of Christ holding a scroll on which are inscribed the Commandments.\n', 'The plurality opinion stated that the monument was constitutional, as it represented historical value and not purely religious value. The primary content is the text of the Ten Commandments. An eagle grasping the American flag, an eye inside of a pyramid, and two small tablets with what appears to be an ancient script are carved above the text of the Ten Commandments. Below the text are two Stars of David and the superimposed Greek letters Chi and Rho, which represent Christ. The bottom of the monument bears the inscription "PRESENTED TO THE PEOPLE AND YOUTH OF TEXAS BY THE FRATERNAL ORDER OF EAGLES OF TEXAS 1961."\n', 'Alter wrote that the instruction of to place the stone tablets of the Ten Commandments in the Tabernacle reflected a common ancient Near Eastern practice of placing documents of solemn contracts within sacred precincts.\n', "The order of the letters of the alphabet is attested from the fourteenth century BCE in the town of Ugarit on Syria's northern coast. Tablets found there bear over one thousand cuneiform signs, but these signs are not Babylonian and there are only thirty distinct characters. About twelve of the tablets have the signs set out in alphabetic order. There are two orders found, one of which is nearly identical to the order used for Hebrew, Greek and Latin, and a second order very similar to that used for Ethiopian.\n", 'According to the Hebrew Bible, the Tables of the Law as they are widely known in English, or Tablets of Stone, Stone Tablets, or Tablets of Testimony (in Hebrew: לוחות הברית "Luchot HaBrit" - "the tablets [of] the covenant") in the Exodus 34:1, were the two pieces of stone inscribed with the Ten Commandments when Moses ascended Mount Sinai as written in the Book of Exodus. Exodus 31:18 refers to the tablets as the "Tablets of (the) Testimony".\n', 'Sometime in the distant past, God dictated the angel scribe Metatron to write a compendium of tablets known as the Word of God. They cover a variety of subjects, including demons, angels, and leviathans. God then sealed the tablets inside the "Vault of the Earth" and even if someone were to find them, only a few chosen humans, the prophets, are able to decipher them. The Leviathan Tablet, which was dug from somewhere in Iran, has an instruction regarding how to kill a leviathan. The Demon Tablet, recovered by Crowley through unknown means, contains an instruction about locking all demons in Hell forever as well as techniques about disposing demons, such as devil\'s traps, holy water, and demon bombs. The Angel Tablet, stored in one of Lucifer\'s crypts, has the information on how to make all angels fall from Heaven as well as an incantation to imbue an angel with great power. The Demon Tablet is currently in the possession of Castiel, who has destroyed the Angel Tablet in the ninth season to prevent Metatron from using its powers.\n', 'The arrangement of the commandments on the two tablets is interpreted in different ways in the classical Jewish tradition. Rabbi Hanina ben Gamaliel says that each tablet contained five commandments, "but the Sages say ten on one tablet and ten on the other", that is, that the tablets were duplicates. This can be compared to diplomatic treaties of the ancient Near East, in which a copy was made for each party.\n', 'The Jewish Chaplain insignia made up of two tablets of the Ten Commandments, with ten Roman numerals symbolizing the commandments, and with the six-pointed Star of David above the tablets, was adopted for Jewish army chaplains in 1917, and for Jewish naval chaplains in 1941. The original Army description did not specifically reference a star "per se", but instead read "a double Tablet bearing numerals from I to X, surmounted by two equilateral Triangles interlaced."\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question of the location of the Tablet of the Ten Commandments, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. This will help clarify the historical, religious, and cultural significance of the tablets, as well as their symbolic representations.

### Extracted Content and Analysis:

1. **Historical Context of the Tablets**:
   - **Passage**: "According to the Hebrew Bible, the Tables of the Law as they are widely known in English, or Tablets of Stone, Stone Tablets, or Tablets of Testimony (in Hebrew: לוחות הברית 'Luchot HaBrit' - 'the tablets [of] the covenant') in the Exodus 34:1, were the two pieces of stone inscribed with the Ten Commandments when Moses ascended Mount Sinai as written in the Book of Exodus."
   - **Analysis**: This passage provides the foundational context for understanding the Ten Commandments. It indicates that the tablets were given to Moses on Mount Sinai, a significant event in Jewish tradition. The term "Tablets of the Law" emphasizes their importance as a covenant between God and the Israelites.

2. **Symbolism and Representation**:
   - **Passage**: "The Ten Commandments appear on the Menorah in their traditional form of two rectangular tablets with rounded tops...symbolizing the burning bush or Mount Sinai aflame at the Giving of the Torah."
   - **Analysis**: This highlights the symbolic representation of the tablets in Jewish culture. The Menorah, a symbol of Judaism, incorporates the tablets, linking them to the divine revelation at Mount Sinai. This connection underscores the tablets' significance in Jewish faith and values.

3. **Cultural Depictions**:
   - **Passage**: "The big cartouche at the top left shows the biblical Israeli leaders Moses and Aaron placing their hands on Israel's Tablets of the Law with the Ten Commandments inscribed in Hebrew."
   - **Analysis**: This passage illustrates how the tablets have been depicted in art and culture, reinforcing their importance in Jewish history. The visual representation of Moses and Aaron with the tablets signifies their role as leaders and mediators of God's laws.

4. **Placement in Sacred Spaces**:
   - **Passage**: "Alter wrote that the instruction of to place the stone tablets of the Ten Commandments in the Tabernacle reflected a common ancient Near Eastern practice of placing documents of solemn contracts within sacred precincts."
   - **Analysis**: This indicates that the tablets were not just physical objects but were treated as sacred documents, akin to contracts in ancient cultures. Their placement in the Tabernacle signifies their ongoing relevance and the reverence with which they were regarded.

5. **Interpretations of the Tablets**:
   - **Passage**: "The arrangement of the commandments on the two tablets is interpreted in different ways in the classical Jewish tradition."
   - **Analysis**: This highlights the diversity of interpretations regarding the tablets, suggesting that their significance is multifaceted. Different traditions may view the tablets as containing either five commandments each or duplicates, reflecting varying theological perspectives.

### Role of Extracted Content:

The extracted content serves several roles in understanding the question about the location of the Tablet of the Ten Commandments:

- **Historical Understanding**: It provides a historical framework for the tablets, situating them within the narrative of the Hebrew Bible and their significance in Jewish tradition.
- **Cultural Significance**: The passages illustrate how the tablets are represented in art and culture, emphasizing their enduring legacy and importance in Jewish identity.
- **Theological Implications**: The discussions around the placement and interpretation of the tablets reveal their theological significance, suggesting that they are more than mere artifacts; they embody a covenantal relationship between God and the people.
- **Symbolic Representation**: The symbolism associated with the tablets, such as their depiction on the Menorah, connects them to broader themes of divine revelation and sacredness in Jewish thought.

In conclusion, while the physical location of the tablets is not definitively stated in the passages, their historical, cultural, and theological contexts provide a rich background for understanding their significance in religious tradition. This knowledge enhances the model's ability to engage with questions about the Ten Commandments and their enduring impact on faith and culture.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Historical Context of the Tablets**:
   - The Ten Commandments were given to Moses on Mount Sinai, as described in the Hebrew Bible (Exodus 34:1). This event is foundational to Jewish tradition, marking a covenant between God and the Israelites. The tablets are referred to in Hebrew as "Luchot HaBrit," meaning "the tablets of the covenant," which emphasizes their significance in establishing the moral and ethical framework for the community.

2. **Symbolism and Representation**:
   - The tablets are often depicted in Jewish art and culture, such as on the Menorah, symbolizing divine revelation. The rounded tops of the tablets and their representation in flames evoke the burning bush and the divine presence at Sinai, reinforcing their sacred nature.

3. **Cultural Depictions**:
   - Artistic representations, such as those showing Moses and Aaron with the tablets, highlight their importance in Jewish history and the role of these leaders as mediators of God's laws. These depictions serve to educate and remind the community of their covenantal relationship with God.

4. **Placement in Sacred Spaces**:
   - The tablets were housed in the Ark of the Covenant, which was kept in the Holy of Holies within the Tabernacle and later in the Temple in Jerusalem. This placement reflects the ancient Near Eastern practice of storing important documents in sacred spaces, indicating the tablets' status as holy and central to worship.

5. **The Fate of the Tablets**:
   - The fate of the Ark of the Covenant and the tablets is uncertain, particularly after the Babylonian conquest of Jerusalem in 586 BCE. Various theories and legends exist regarding their whereabouts, including the possibility that they were hidden or destroyed. This uncertainty adds to their mystique and significance in religious thought.

6. **Interpretations of the Tablets**:
   - Different interpretations exist regarding the arrangement of the commandments on the tablets, with some traditions suggesting that each tablet contained five commandments, while others propose that both tablets contained the same commandments. This diversity reflects the rich theological discourse surrounding the tablets.

### Answer:
The tablets of the Ten Commandments were traditionally housed in the Ark of the Covenant, which was kept in the Holy of Holies within the Tabernacle and later in the Temple in Jerusalem. However, their current location is unknown, as they are believed to have been lost or hidden during the Babylonian conquest of Jerusalem in 586 BCE. Various theories and legends exist about their whereabouts, but there is no definitive evidence of their current location. The significance of the tablets extends beyond their physical presence; they symbolize the covenant between God and the Israelites and embody the moral and ethical framework central to Jewish faith and identity.

Task Description:

Carefully extract the most relevant foundational and advanced knowledge from these passages, with a particular focus on how the context of the retrieved information relates to the question. Consider the background, nuances, and circumstances under which the information was generated or used. Finally, summarize and integrate these insights to construct a well-contextualized foundation for answering the question.

To address the question of where the tablet of the Ten Commandments is located, we can draw from the provided passages to construct a contextual understanding of the tablets' historical, religious, and cultural significance.

1. **Historical Context**: According to the Hebrew Bible, specifically in the Book of Exodus, the Ten Commandments were inscribed on two stone tablets that Moses received from God on Mount Sinai (as noted in the passage referencing Exodus 34:1). This event is central to Jewish tradition and signifies the establishment of a covenant between God and the Israelites.

2. **Physical Location**: The tablets were originally placed in the Ark of the Covenant, a sacred container that was housed within the Tabernacle, a portable sanctuary used by the Israelites during their wanderings in the desert. The mention of placing the tablets in the Tabernacle reflects ancient Near Eastern practices of storing important documents in sacred spaces (as noted in the passage discussing the Tabernacle).

3. **Cultural Representations**: The tablets have been depicted in various forms throughout history, including artistic representations such as the portable altarpiece by the Master of the Altarpiece of the Ten Commandments, which illustrates scenes related to the commandments (as mentioned in the passage about the German painter). These artistic interpretations highlight the enduring cultural significance of the commandments beyond their original religious context.

4. **Modern Symbolism**: In contemporary times, the Ten Commandments continue to be represented in various forms, including monuments and insignias, such as the Jewish Chaplain insignia that features the tablets alongside the Star of David (as noted in the passage about the insignia). This demonstrates the ongoing relevance of the commandments in modern religious and cultural identity.

5. **Interpretations and Variations**: There are differing interpretations regarding the arrangement of the commandments on the tablets. Some traditions hold that each tablet contained five commandments, while others suggest that both tablets contained the same ten commandments (as discussed in the passage about Rabbi Hanina ben Gamaliel). This reflects the complexity and richness of the tradition surrounding the commandments.

### Summary
The tablets of the Ten Commandments, according to biblical tradition, were inscribed on stone and given to Moses on Mount Sinai, later housed in the Ark of the Covenant within the Tabernacle. Their historical and religious significance has led to various representations and interpretations throughout history, including artistic depictions and modern symbols. While the physical location of the original tablets is not definitively known today, their legacy continues to resonate in both religious and cultural contexts. Thus, the question of "where" the tablets are can be understood both in terms of their historical placement and their enduring symbolic presence in contemporary society.

### Context-enhanced reasoning process:
To address the question of where the tablet of the Ten Commandments is located, it is essential to consider both the historical and religious contexts surrounding the tablets, as well as their cultural significance over time.

1. **Historical Context**: The Ten Commandments were inscribed on two stone tablets given to Moses by God on Mount Sinai, as described in the Book of Exodus (Exodus 34:1). This event is foundational to Jewish tradition, marking the establishment of a covenant between God and the Israelites. The tablets symbolize divine law and moral guidance.

2. **Physical Location**: Historically, the tablets were housed in the Ark of the Covenant, a sacred container that was kept in the Holy of Holies within the Tabernacle during the Israelites' desert wanderings. The Tabernacle served as a portable sanctuary, reflecting ancient Near Eastern practices of safeguarding important documents in sacred spaces. Later, the Ark was placed in the Temple in Jerusalem, which further solidified its significance.

3. **Loss and Uncertainty**: The fate of the Ark and the tablets is uncertain, particularly following the Babylonian conquest of Jerusalem in 586 BCE. Historical accounts suggest that the Ark may have been lost or hidden during this tumultuous period, leading to various theories and legends about its current whereabouts. This uncertainty adds a layer of intrigue and mystery to the tablets' history.

4. **Cultural Representations**: Over the centuries, the Ten Commandments have been depicted in various artistic forms, such as altarpieces and monuments. These representations, including the portable altarpiece by the Master of the Altarpiece of the Ten Commandments, illustrate the commandments' enduring cultural significance and their role in religious art and iconography.

5. **Modern Symbolism**: In contemporary society, the Ten Commandments continue to hold relevance, represented in various forms such as monuments and insignias. For example, the Jewish Chaplain insignia features the tablets alongside the Star of David, highlighting their importance in modern religious and cultural identity.

6. **Interpretations and Variations**: Different interpretations exist regarding the arrangement of the commandments on the tablets. Some traditions assert that each tablet contained five commandments, while others believe both tablets contained the same ten commandments. This reflects the complexity of the tradition and its interpretations over time.

### Final Answer:
The tablets of the Ten Commandments are traditionally believed to have been housed in the Ark of the Covenant, which was kept in the Holy of Holies within the Tabernacle and later in the Temple in Jerusalem. However, their current location is unknown, as they are thought to have been lost or hidden during the Babylonian conquest of Jerusalem in 586 BCE. The legacy of the tablets continues to resonate in both religious and cultural contexts, symbolizing divine law and moral guidance throughout history.

logician.content:
You are a logician, to answer the following question:
where is the tablet of the ten commandments
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Ten Commandments appear on the Menorah in their traditional form of two rectangular tablets with rounded tops. Written on the tablets are the Ten Commandments as given at Mount Sinai encapsulating the basic tenets of Jewish faith and values. Each commandment is represented on the tablets by the first two words of the full commandment. Flames rise in the background of the tablets, symbolizing the burning bush or Mount Sinai aflame at the Giving of the Torah.
', 'The map has decorative enframes-cartouches on its sides, with two big cartouches at the top quadrants and two small ones at the bottom quadrants. The big cartouche at the top left shows the biblical Israeli leaders Moses and Aaron placing their hands on Israel's Tablets of the Law with the Ten Commandments inscribed in Hebrew. Above them at the top of the cartouche frame within another frame, appears a caption of the Hebrew word "יְהֹוָה" - "YHWH", the tetragrammaton as the most sacred name of God. The big cartouche at the top right quadrant shows the biblical story of Adam and Eve in Paradise, which is based on Albrecht Dürer's engraving from 1504 under the title "Adam and Eve" - with small differences between the two. Above them at the top of the cartouche frame within another frame, appears a caption of the Hebrew word "אֱלֹהִים" - "Elohim" as the second name of God. The small cartouche at the bottom left quadrant shows a heraldic eagle and an inscription to sir Robert Cotton who encouraged Speed to start drawing maps.
', 'The Master of the Altarpiece of the Ten Commandments () was a German painter active in the region of Göttingen at the beginning of the fifteenth century. His name is derived from a portable altarpiece, depicting the Ten Commandments, which is believed to have at one time stood in the chapel of the Sacred Heart in Göttingen, constructed in 1319. Only the central part of the painting survives, today in the history museum in Hannover; it depicts six scenes in two registers, showing the second, third, fourth, seventh, eight, and ninth Commandments. The wings, illustrating the other four, are now lost. At the top of the composition is a half-length figure of Christ holding a scroll on which are inscribed the Commandments.
', 'The plurality opinion stated that the monument was constitutional, as it represented historical value and not purely religious value. The primary content is the text of the Ten Commandments. An eagle grasping the American flag, an eye inside of a pyramid, and two small tablets with what appears to be an ancient script are carved above the text of the Ten Commandments. Below the text are two Stars of David and the superimposed Greek letters Chi and Rho, which represent Christ. The bottom of the monument bears the inscription "PRESENTED TO THE PEOPLE AND YOUTH OF TEXAS BY THE FRATERNAL ORDER OF EAGLES OF TEXAS 1961."
', 'Alter wrote that the instruction of to place the stone tablets of the Ten Commandments in the Tabernacle reflected a common ancient Near Eastern practice of placing documents of solemn contracts within sacred precincts.
', "The order of the letters of the alphabet is attested from the fourteenth century BCE in the town of Ugarit on Syria's northern coast. Tablets found there bear over one thousand cuneiform signs, but these signs are not Babylonian and there are only thirty distinct characters. About twelve of the tablets have the signs set out in alphabetic order. There are two orders found, one of which is nearly identical to the order used for Hebrew, Greek and Latin, and a second order very similar to that used for Ethiopian.
", 'According to the Hebrew Bible, the Tables of the Law as they are widely known in English, or Tablets of Stone, Stone Tablets, or Tablets of Testimony (in Hebrew: לוחות הברית "Luchot HaBrit" - "the tablets [of] the covenant") in the Exodus 34:1, were the two pieces of stone inscribed with the Ten Commandments when Moses ascended Mount Sinai as written in the Book of Exodus. Exodus 31:18 refers to the tablets as the "Tablets of (the) Testimony".
', 'Sometime in the distant past, God dictated the angel scribe Metatron to write a compendium of tablets known as the Word of God. They cover a variety of subjects, including demons, angels, and leviathans. God then sealed the tablets inside the "Vault of the Earth" and even if someone were to find them, only a few chosen humans, the prophets, are able to decipher them. The Leviathan Tablet, which was dug from somewhere in Iran, has an instruction regarding how to kill a leviathan. The Demon Tablet, recovered by Crowley through unknown means, contains an instruction about locking all demons in Hell forever as well as techniques about disposing demons, such as devil's traps, holy water, and demon bombs. The Angel Tablet, stored in one of Lucifer's crypts, has the information on how to make all angels fall from Heaven as well as an incantation to imbue an angel with great power. The Demon Tablet is currently in the possession of Castiel, who has destroyed the Angel Tablet in the ninth season to prevent Metatron from using its powers.
', 'The arrangement of the commandments on the two tablets is interpreted in different ways in the classical Jewish tradition. Rabbi Hanina ben Gamaliel says that each tablet contained five commandments, "but the Sages say ten on one tablet and ten on the other", that is, that the tablets were duplicates. This can be compared to diplomatic treaties of the ancient Near East, in which a copy was made for each party.
', 'The Jewish Chaplain insignia made up of two tablets of the Ten Commandments, with ten Roman numerals symbolizing the commandments, and with the six-pointed Star of David above the tablets, was adopted for Jewish army chaplains in 1917, and for Jewish naval chaplains in 1941. The original Army description did not specifically reference a star "per se", but instead read "a double Tablet bearing numerals from I to X, surmounted by two equilateral Triangles interlaced."
']

2. **Symbolism and Representation**:
   - The tablets are often depicted with flames, symbolizing divine revelation (the burning bush or Mount Sinai aflame).
   - Artistic representations, such as the altarpiece by the Master of the Altarpiece of the Ten Commandments, illustrate the commandments and their significance in religious art.

3. **Cultural and Legal Interpretations**:
   - The arrangement of the commandments on the tablets varies in interpretation, with some traditions suggesting each tablet contained five commandments, while others propose that both tablets contained duplicates of all ten.
   - The practice of placing important documents within sacred spaces reflects ancient Near Eastern customs, suggesting a broader cultural context for the tablets.

4. **Modern Representations**:
   - The Ten Commandments are represented in various monuments and insignia, such as the Jewish Chaplain insignia, which incorporates the tablets and symbols like the Star of David.
   - Legal and historical discussions around the display of the Ten Commandments in public spaces highlight their ongoing relevance and the debate over their religious versus historical significance.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Contextual Relationships**:

2. **Symbolic Interpretation**:

3. **Diverse Perspectives**:

The historical context, symbolic meanings, diverse interpretations, and contemporary relevance of the Ten Commandments all contribute to a more nuanced understanding of human thought and behavior, which is essential for effective reasoning and inference in various domains.

The map has decorative enframes-cartouches on its sides, with two big cartouches at the top quadrants and two small ones at the bottom quadrants. The big cartouche at the top left shows the biblical Israeli leaders Moses and Aaron placing their hands on Israel's Tablets of the Law with the Ten Commandments inscribed in Hebrew. Above them at the top of the cartouche frame within another frame, appears a caption of the Hebrew word "יְהֹוָה" - "YHWH", the tetragrammaton as the most sacred name of God. The big cartouche at the top right quadrant shows the biblical story of Adam and Eve in Paradise, which is based on Albrecht Dürer's engraving from 1504 under the title "Adam and Eve" - with small differences between the two. Above them at the top of the cartouche frame within another frame, appears a caption of the Hebrew word "אֱלֹהִים" - "Elohim" as the second name of God. The small cartouche at the bottom left quadrant shows a heraldic eagle and an inscription to sir Robert Cotton who encouraged Speed to start drawing maps.
The Master of the Altarpiece of the Ten Commandments () was a German painter active in the region of Göttingen at the beginning of the fifteenth century. His name is derived from a portable altarpiece, depicting the Ten Commandments, which is believed to have at one time stood in the chapel of the Sacred Heart in Göttingen, constructed in 1319. Only the central part of the painting survives, today in the history museum in Hannover; it depicts six scenes in two registers, showing the second, third, fourth, seventh, eight, and ninth Commandments. The wings, illustrating the other four, are now lost. At the top of the composition is a half-length figure of Christ holding a scroll on which are inscribed the Commandments.
The plurality opinion stated that the monument was constitutional, as it represented historical value and not purely religious value. The primary content is the text of the Ten Commandments. An eagle grasping the American flag, an eye inside of a pyramid, and two small tablets with what appears to be an ancient script are carved above the text of the Ten Commandments. Below the text are two Stars of David and the superimposed Greek letters Chi and Rho, which represent Christ. The bottom of the monument bears the inscription "PRESENTED TO THE PEOPLE AND YOUTH OF TEXAS BY THE FRATERNAL ORDER OF EAGLES OF TEXAS 1961."
Alter wrote that the instruction of to place the stone tablets of the Ten Commandments in the Tabernacle reflected a common ancient Near Eastern practice of placing documents of solemn contracts within sacred precincts.
The order of the letters of the alphabet is attested from the fourteenth century BCE in the town of Ugarit on Syria's northern coast. Tablets found there bear over one thousand cuneiform signs, but these signs are not Babylonian and there are only thirty distinct characters. About twelve of the tablets have the signs set out in alphabetic order. There are two orders found, one of which is nearly identical to the order used for Hebrew, Greek and Latin, and a second order very similar to that used for Ethiopian.
According to the Hebrew Bible, the Tables of the Law as they are widely known in English, or Tablets of Stone, Stone Tablets, or Tablets of Testimony (in Hebrew: לוחות הברית "Luchot HaBrit" - "the tablets [of] the covenant") in the Exodus 34:1, were the two pieces of stone inscribed with the Ten Commandments when Moses ascended Mount Sinai as written in the Book of Exodus. Exodus 31:18 refers to the tablets as the "Tablets of (the) Testimony".
Sometime in the distant past, God dictated the angel scribe Metatron to write a compendium of tablets known as the Word of God. They cover a variety of subjects, including demons, angels, and leviathans. God then sealed the tablets inside the "Vault of the Earth" and even if someone were to find them, only a few chosen humans, the prophets, are able to decipher them. The Leviathan Tablet, which was dug from somewhere in Iran, has an instruction regarding how to kill a leviathan. The Demon Tablet, recovered by Crowley through unknown means, contains an instruction about locking all demons in Hell forever as well as techniques about disposing demons, such as devil's traps, holy water, and demon bombs. The Angel Tablet, stored in one of Lucifer's crypts, has the information on how to make all angels fall from Heaven as well as an incantation to imbue an angel with great power. The Demon Tablet is currently in the possession of Castiel, who has destroyed the Angel Tablet in the ninth season to prevent Metatron from using its powers.
The arrangement of the commandments on the two tablets is interpreted in different ways in the classical Jewish tradition. Rabbi Hanina ben Gamaliel says that each tablet contained five commandments, "but the Sages say ten on one tablet and ten on the other", that is, that the tablets were duplicates. This can be compared to diplomatic treaties of the ancient Near East, in which a copy was made for each party.
The Jewish Chaplain insignia made up of two tablets of the Ten Commandments, with ten Roman numerals symbolizing the commandments, and with the six-pointed Star of David above the tablets, was adopted for Jewish army chaplains in 1917, and for Jewish naval chaplains in 1941. The original Army description did not specifically reference a star "per se", but instead read "a double Tablet bearing numerals from I to X, surmounted by two equilateral Triangles interlaced."
__answers__: in the Ark of the Covenant
